floodArea.county: County Durham, Hartlepool, North Tyneside, South Tyneside, Sunderland

items.message:
Large and powerful waves are expected to affect the foreshore as a result of high spring tides and strong winds. Tides will be at their highest between 07:00 and 11:00 tomorrow morning, 16/09/22, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.
We expect flooding to affect beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. The area most likely to be affected is Seaham Harbour and docks. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
We are closely monitoring the situation. This Alert may stay in force for the evening high tide, 16/09/22.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated at 12:00 tomorrow afternoon, 16/09/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for reduced flood risk from high tides however further alerts may be issued over the next few days due to the weather conditions. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is possible from 12pm this afternoon, Thursday 15th September and over the next 24hrs. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. The current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak, and will fall away over the next few days, allowing the freshwater river flows to drain out to sea at low tide as normal again. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 8:30am tomorrow, Friday 16th September.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message: The flood alert for the North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including the tidal River Esk has been issued for tomorrow's tides. The area of particular concern is Sandsend, with wind driven wave overtopping expected from 08:00 until 12:15 on the morning tide, and from 20:30 until 00:15 on the evening tide, on Friday 16 September. Strong northerly winds are likely to produce overtopping waves and spray along the coast, especially around Sandsend. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast closely. This message will be updated by 09:30 on Friday morning, 16 September, or as the situation changes.
Water levels in the Eastern Yar are now falling. The weather is expected to be dry through to the weekend giving river levels time to recover.
